# Slim deployments

<div class="tip">

**ðŸ’¡ Tip:** Once your dbt project is ready to move out of development,
or as soon as you start managing multiple users and deployment
environments, we recommend checking the code in to **version control**
and setting up an **automated workflow** to control the deployment of
changes.

</div>

On each run, dbt generates
[artifacts](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/artifacts/dbt-artifacts)
with metadata about your dbt project, including the [*manifest
file*](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/artifacts/manifest-json)
(`manifest.json`). This file contains a complete representation of the
latest state of your project, and you can use it to **avoid re-deploying
resources that didnâ€™t change** since the last run.

We recommend using the slim deployment pattern when you want to reduce
development idle time and CI costs in development environments. For
production deployments, you should prefer the [blue/green deployment
pattern](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/manage/dbt/blue-green-deployments/).

<div class="note">

**NOTE:** Check [this
demo](https://github.com/morsapaes/dbt-ci-templates) for a sample
end-to-end workflow using GitHub and GitHub Actions.

</div>

1.  Fetch the production `manifest.json` file into the CI environment:

    <div class="highlight">

    ``` chroma
          - name: Download production manifest from s3
            env:
              AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
              AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
              AWS_SESSION_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.AWS_SESSION_TOKEN }}
              AWS_REGION: us-east-1
            run: |
              aws s3 cp s3://mz-test-dbt/manifest.json ./manifest.json
    ```

    </div>

2.  Then, instruct dbt to run and test changed models and dependencies
    only:

    <div class="highlight">

    ``` chroma
          - name: Build dbt
            env:
              MZ_HOST: ${{ secrets.MZ_HOST }}
              MZ_USER: ${{ secrets.MZ_USER }}
              MZ_PASSWORD: ${{ secrets.MZ_PASSWORD }}
              CI_TAG: "${{ format('{0}_{1}', 'gh_ci', github.event.number ) }}"
            run: |
              source .venv/bin/activate
              dbt run-operation drop_environment
              dbt build --profiles-dir ./ --select state:modified+ --state ./ --target production
    ```

    </div>

    In the example above, `--select state:modified+` instructs dbt to
    run all models that were modified (`state:modified`) and their
    downstream dependencies (`+`). Depending on your deployment
    requirements, you might want to use a different combination of state
    selectors, or go a step further and use the
    [`--defer`](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/node-selection/defer)
    flag to reduce even more the number of models that need to be
    rebuilt. For a full rundown of the available [state
    modifier](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/node-selection/methods#the-state-method)
    and [graph
    operator](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/node-selection/graph-operators)
    options, check the [dbt
    documentation](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/node-selection/syntax).

3.  Every time you deploy to production, upload the new `manifest.json`
    file to blob storage (e.g. s3):

    <div class="highlight">

    ``` chroma
          - name: upload new manifest to s3
            env:
              AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
              AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
              AWS_SESSION_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.AWS_SESSION_TOKEN }}
              AWS_REGION: us-east-1
            run: |
              aws s3 cp ./target/manifest.json s3://mz-test-dbt
    ```

    </div>

</div>
